reasoning: The critique targets a genuinely important support for the essay’s “eutopia is fragile” intuition—Section 2.4’s multiplicative ‘product of factors’ model—so refuting that would weaken one major route to ‘mostly-great futures are rare.’ However, the overall position is also supported by additional considerations (e.g., the long list of plausible moral failure modes and the more systematic Section 3 discussion of bounded/unbounded/fussy value functions), so this attack is not position-collapsing (centrality ~0.4). The critique’s argument is directionally plausible (many moral theories allow compensation/additivity), but it’s underdeveloped: it doesn’t engage with why the authors think single flaws can erase “most value,” doesn’t show that plausible aggregators are sufficiently substitutable, and overclaims about distributional effects (additivity doesn’t imply ‘common eutopia’; you can still get rare near-optima under many additive/threshold/lexical or heavy-tail setups). Thus it only modestly weakens the attacked component (strength ~0.3). Most claims are broadly correct but some are too strong or underspecified (correctness ~0.7). It is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Compensatory value aggregation makes eutopia less fragile than the multiplicative model suggests
